online.game
Class stackCell<FINALTYPE extends stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>,COMPONENTTYPE extends chip<?>>

java.lang.Object
  online.game.cell<FINALTYPE>
      online.game.stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Digestable, Drawable, UniversalConstants, Play2Constants, PlayConstants
Direct Known Subclasses:
CheckerCell
public abstract class stackCell<FINALTYPE extends stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>,COMPONENTTYPE extends chip<?>>
extends cell<FINALTYPE>

stackCell extends cell with a stack of chips. The stack size is expanded as necessary. Either stackCell or chipCell should be the basis for the cells of the board and other repositories of game bits. Even if the game doesn't stack chips, it's sometimes convenient to use stackCell so piles of extra or captured chips can be used.

Author:
ddyer
See Also:
chipCell, cell

copyAllFrom

public void copyAllFrom(FINALTYPE other)
clone the dynamic state of the cell from a cell on another board, and copy the stack contents. It's assumed that the stack consists of immutable objects so the structure can be shared.

Digest

public long Digest(Random r)
generate a digest of the stack. This version considers the order of the items in the stack to be significant. To get unique digests for the whole game, each cell should be digested just once. When the same cells are encountered multiple times, the "extra" encounters should use this form so the digest is different from the "normal" version.

Specified by:
Digest in interface Digestable
Overrides:
Digest in class cell<FINALTYPE extends stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>>
Parameters:
r - a random variable.
Returns:
an integer

Digest

public long Digest()
generate a digest of the stack. This version considers the order of the items to be significant. This version without a specific random context should be used only for the "default" digest of an item in it's usual context.

Specified by:
Digest in interface Digestable
Overrides:
Digest in class cell<FINALTYPE extends stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>>
Returns:
an integer

contentsString

public java.lang.String contentsString()
generate a representation of the contents of the stack, by calling contentsString() of each element of the stack. This is used so the debugger will present useful representations of the stacks you see.

Overrides:
contentsString in class cell<FINALTYPE extends stackCell<FINALTYPE,COMPONENTTYPE>>
Returns:
a reasonably brief printable string

stackBaseLevel

public int stackBaseLevel()
level of a stack considered to be the floor. Most stacks use 0, but some stacks start with a background tile at level 0, with movable chips starting at level 1. This is used to calculate stack height for drawStack "liftSteps" parameter, and also for the x-axis jog of stacks at multiples of 5 height.

Returns:
an integer
See Also:
#isEmpty()} {@link #height()}

drawStackTickSize

public int drawStackTickSize(int sz)
return the size of glitches in stacks, to make the height of the stack visually countable. defaults to sz/10

Parameters:
sz -
Returns:
the number of pixels to jink

stackXAdjust

public int stackXAdjust(double xscale,
                        int lift,
                        int SQUARESIZE)
return the X offset for the n'th chip in the stack. Normally this is just linear, but some special cases can be accommodated here. For example, twixt the bridges are all drawn at height 1.

stackYAdjust

public int stackYAdjust(double yscale,
                        int lift,
                        int SQUARESIZE)
return the Y offset for the n'th chip in the stack. Normally this is just linear, but some special cases can be accommodated here. For example, twixt the bridges are all drawn at height 1.

drawStackTickLocation

public int drawStackTickLocation()
return the position of ticks in stacks. The default is every 5 chips, but some games (ie; tintas) make some other number more appropriate.

Returns:
a height index for the tick

labelAllChips

public boolean labelAllChips()
if true, pass the label to each chip in a stack. Use this when you're using the label to affect drawing behavior in ad-hoc ways

Returns:
true if each chip should be labeled separately

drawStack

public boolean drawStack(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                         exCanvas canvas,
                         HitPoint highlight,
                         int SQUARESIZE,
                         int xpos,
                         int ypos,
                         int liftSteps,
                         double xscale,
                         double yscale,
                         java.lang.String label)
draw a stack of chips, and detect the mouse inside the stack.

Parameters:
gc - the graphics
canvas - the canvas to draw on
highlight - the highlight which collects mouse hit info
SQUARESIZE - the square size
xpos - the x position of the base of the stack
ypos - the y position of the base of the stack
liftSteps - the number of lift steps
xscale - the x scale for each lift step
yscale - the y scale for each lift step
label - a label or null
Returns:
true if any call to drawChip(java.awt.Graphics, online.common.exCanvas, int, int, int, java.lang.String) returned true. Effectively this should be if the mouse hit any chip in the stack. If true, HitPoint.hitIndex is set to the first index that registered as a hit.
